learning_outcomes.description: Describe the major principles of sustainable development;
Apply the principles of sustainable development to a range of issues, and propose practical improvements;
Critically analyse and debate contentious topics in sustainable development;
Assess the conflicts and trade-offs inherent in sustainable development;
Discuss the interests and roles of multiple stakeholders in promoting sustainable development;
Effectively use verbal and written communication skills to articulate knowledge;
Source, read and demonstrate an understanding of academic literature in relation to sustainable development issues;
Work both in groups and independently toward a better understanding and promotion of sustainable development;
Demonstrate a mature understanding of the causes, consequences and potential solutions to pressing sustainable development issues.

assessments.task_description:
Length: 2,000-2,500 words (excluding references, appendices, endnotes and footnotes)

Aim: Sustainable development is a broad, complex and multi-disciplinary area of study. As such, this assessment piece is designed to:

  • Meet the various and diverse interests of students yet still allow them to be immersed in the core principles of sustainable development.
  • Provide an opportunity for students to explore some concepts from the course in more detail.
  • Develop skills in reading and critically analysing literature from a diverse range of disciplines.
  • Develop skills in research writing and the ability to communicate a complex matter in a professional style, based on reading and critical thought.

Task Description: This is an individual assignment. Students work independently and write a research paper on sustainable development. Students are required to select their preferred topic (from the list of topics provided) by 2:00PM, 12 August (Week 4). A spreadsheet will be provided on the course Blackboard for students to identify their selected topic. There is a cap on the number of students for each topic (depending on the total number of students in each practical).

assessments.task_description:
It is an important part of your learning to participate in all activities in the practicals. There are 10 practicals for this course, 9 of them directly correspond with lecture content and course readings. This assessment item relates to your external/online participation in the activities in these 9 practicals. Each week, students will form small groups to answer the questions related to the weekly readings and create a poster.

Practicals in week 11 will host your Conference Presentations.

assessments.task_description:
Length: Online/Virtual Conference presentations should be focused as time is limited to eight (8) minutes presentation + two (2) minutes Q&A and content slides are limited to six (6) in total (excluding title slide and references slide); Abstracts should be 150-200 words in length.

Students that worked on the same research paper topic will form a group. Each group will select a case study relevant to their research paper topic and prepare and deliver a conference presentation to the class. The presentation will be focused on critically analysing the case study. It is an opportunity for each student to undertake an in-depth and detailed analysis of their research paper topic, by focusing on a specific real-world example. The case study can be a project, an initiative, an industry, a place (e.g. suburb, city, country, developed or developing countries, etc), a group of people (e.g. a specific gender, social, cultural group, etc) etc. The conference presentation should:

  • Present an overview of the issue students researched in their research paper;
  • Introduce the case study;
  • Summarise the major social, economic and environmental dimensions of the case study; and
  • Identify some solutions or recommendation for promoting sustainable development related to the case study and discuss some of the key challenges in providing the solutions/recommendations.

The presentation should be pithy and catchy. It should captivate the audience and spur interest and even motivation for action. Further information on this assessment item, including the marking criteria, see document attached below.

It is up to each student as to how you prepare and deliver this presentation, but please make sure that you all equally participate in specific tasks. A group peer assessment form is available to you to complete. If no group peer assessment is submitted by 5:00PM at your presentation day, course staff will assume equal contribution of all group members and thus all students in a group will yield the same final mark.

Following your group’s conference presentation, the audience will be invited to ask questions. So be prepared for up to two (2) minutes of question time on your presentation.
